introSection.value: Each dot is a person, square is a paper.
We focus on the trajectory of a single person.

zoomingIn.value: **Setup**: We first color co-author nodes by author age difference (as shown in the legend), while node size is proportional to the number of collaborations. For the papers, we use the square root scaling nodes with citation count, binding node size between a radius 3 and 15 pixels. Note that we use total citation as of 2024, while collaboration is cumulative collaboration count. A cool viz could be to look at relative growth of paper node size, in terms of citation, while exploring the timeline

**Early Career Foundation (1999-2006)**: Peter Sheridan Dodds's first 8 years show the initial formation of his research network. Notice the sparse but foundational collaborations that would shape his academic trajectory. We can see here that the first few papers he collaborated we older coauthors, as one would expect, but also  many collaborators of the same age.

Hiring: If we look at shared affiliation with coauthors, we can see a typical patterns for early career researchers. We can see that he started out at MIT, before moving on to Columbia. He briefly collaborated with people at the Santa Fe Institute, perhaps for a Post-doctoral fellowship, then did the rest of his career at University of Vermont. We can corroborate this information by looking up his CV, which indicate that his PHD was indeed at MIT, while he did a postdoc at Columbia, but not the Santa Fe Institute. He started out at UVM as assistant professor earlier than we thought, in 2006.

**Faculty first years**: The hallmark of having a research group is that you collaborate much more extensively with younger collaborators, as you become a mentor. Across domains, it happens in different ways. In this case, we can also see something different.

**Power of two**: The size of each circle represents the total number of collaborations with that person. The complete picture reveals recurrent collaborations, here with professor Danforth.
